channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: postcards from the hajj: At Mount Arafat, Water Fights and Prayers — for Peace and, Yes, for a Husband
item.media:description: During the second day of the hajj, pilgrims prayed at Mount Arafat on Sunday.
item.description: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent in Mecca for the hajj, observed the latest trends there and confronted a mountain of water bottles.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Spate of Deadly Attacks in Syria Ahead of Cease-Fire
item.media:description: Syrian men carrying babies made their way through the rubble of destroyed buildings after a reported airstrike on a rebel-held neighborhood in Aleppo on Sunday.
item.description: At least 91 people have been killed in strikes on rebel-held areas in the two days since Russia and the United States declared that a cease-fire would begin on Monday.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: After Centuries of Loss, Seeds of Hope for Argentina’s Indigenous People
item.media:description: Fermín Acuña, vice president of the Ranquel Chieftains Council in Santa Rosa, Argentina, at a monument where the prominent 19th-century chieftain Panguithruz Güor is buried. The Ranquel recovered this stretch of land in 2001 and moved his remains there from a museum.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Ranquel communities have emerged as patient champions of indigenous rights in a nation that is conflicted about the past and about the appropriate response now.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Repeat of Austria’s Presidential Runoff Faces a Delay
item.media:description: Alexander Van der Bellen, left, and Norbert Hofer, the candidates in the Austrian presidential election, at a debate in May.
item.description: The country’s interior minister said faulty postal ballots meant the vote should be postponed, another embarrassing glitch in an election originally held in May.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: With Spain in Political Deadlock, Catalans Renew Calls for Independence
item.description: Hundreds of thousands took to the streets of Barcelona and four other cities to urge their leaders to push for separation from Spain.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Marriage Falls in China, Transforming Finances and Families
item.media:description: Wu Jingjing, 29, at a Beijing theater. Ms. Wu, who is single and works at an internet company, says young people no longer just want someone to marry, they want a relationship based on love.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: The drop in marriage stems in part from China’s aging population, but also reflects that women who once were pushed to wed are exploring new options.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG and ZHANG TIANTIAN

item.title: The Interpreter: How Countries Like the Philippines Fall Into Vigilante Violence
item.media:description: A Filipino woman hugged her husband after an unidentified gunman killed him in Manila on July 23. The placard at their feet read, “I’m a pusher.”
item.description: Social scientists who study extrajudicial killings say the real story is more complicated — and more tragic — than a simple story of good versus evil.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: South Sudan Leaders Amass Great Wealth as Nation Suffers, Report Says
item.media:description: South Sudanese refugees in the remote northwestern district of Adjumani, in Uganda, near the border with South Sudan in August.
item.description: A report by an advocacy group in Washington suggests that a desire to control of natural resources, not an ethnic feud, is at the root of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Militia Seizes Libyan Oil Terminals in Challenge to Government
item.description: A militia attacked and seized as many as three major oil terminals, not long after the militia that had held them signed a deal with the unity government to resume oil exports.
item.dc:creator: SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Conservative Party in Croatia Wins Parliamentary Elections
item.description: The Croatian Democratic Union captured 61 seats, more than the rival Social Democrats but short of a clear governing majority.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Angela Merkel’s Problems in Germany Could Challenge Europe, Too
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Berlin last week. As next year’s national elections approach, she is more politically vulnerable than at any time since her early days in office.
item.description: The chancellor is under growing political pressure over her migration policy at a time when the Continent is looking for strong leadership.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: San Lorenzo di Lerchi Journal: Italian Grows Forgotten Fruit. What She Preserves Is a Culture.
item.media:description: Isabella Dalla Ragione picking apples on her farmstead in San Lorenzo di Lerchi, Italy.
item.media:credit: Francesco Lastrucci for The New York Times
item.description: Like her father before her, Isabella Dalla Ragione scours the countryside in search of varieties that no longer satisfy agricultural trends, market demands and modern tastes.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Ireland Doesn’t Want Apple’s Back Taxes, but the Irish Aren’t So Sure
item.media:description: Apple’s campus in Cork, Ireland. The company has had a presence in Cork since the early 1980s.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: After six years of belt-tightening and tax increases, many Irish workers say their government’s reluctance to collect $14.5 billion from Apple is unfair.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Afghan Police Chief Is Killed as He Tries to Turn Tide Against Taliban
item.description: The police chief, Gen. Zarawar Zahid, was visiting an outpost when explosives detonated. The Taliban claimed responsibility for his death.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Tianjin Mayor Caught Up in Xi’s Antigraft Campaign
item.media:description: Huang Xingguo, the mayor of Tianjin, at an unveiling ceremony in April 2015. The official was ‘‘suspected of severe disciplinary violations,” but the announcement did not describe specific charges against him.
item.description: An announcement said the official was “suspected of severe disciplinary violations,” which usually means taking bribes or other kinds of corruption.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)

item.title: News Analysis: Few Expect China to Punish North Korea for Latest Nuclear Test
item.media:description: A man standing on a bridge over the Yalu River that once linked the cities of Sinuiju in North Korea and Dandong in China’s Liaoning Province.
item.description: Pyongyang’s aggression is an embarrassment for Beijing, but a collapsed North Korean regime worries Chinese leaders much more, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: What in the World: Turkey’s Suspicious Mind-Set Has Been a Century in the Making
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photography by Filip Fuxa/shutterstock
item.description: The Turks’ notion of a vast Western conspiracy to undermine their country, with the United States mostly to blame, has its roots in a post-World War I treaty that was never carried out.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: What in the World: Something Old, Something New, Something Borrowed, Something Hindu
item.description: A traditional Indian wedding can last days, and rituals include the bride kicking over a pot of rice and dance competitions between Team Bride and Team Groom.
item.dc:creator: AMISHA PADNANI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Anti-Semitism and the British Left
item.description: Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership of the Labour Party has alienated Britain’s Jews.
item.dc:creator: DAVE RICH

item.title: Editorial: Suing Journalists in Mexico
item.media:description: Carmen Aristegui during a meeting with members of the media in Mexico City in July.
item.description: The impact of Mexico’s new anticorruption law depends on the ability of journalists to do critical work without facing specious lawsuits.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Opinion: The Flavors That Unite Syrians
item.description: Food is what defines the people of Syria, even after years of war and displacement.
item.dc:creator: DALIA MORTADA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Readers React: Seeing Orange: What Caught Commenters’ Eyes About a Small Syrian Boy in a Big Chair
item.media:description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo.
item.description: Our Photo Editors’ Notebook on what made the image of Omran Daqneesh stand out inspired many readers to share their thoughts.
item.dc:creator: INSIDER STAFF
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
